medium_description_en: Quantifies severity of heart failure in ACS and predicts 30-day mortality.

seo.meta_description_en: The Killip Classification for Heart Failure quantifies severity of heart failure in NSTEMI and predicts 30-day mortality.
seo.keywords_en: Killip class, killip classification for heart failure, heart failure, killip heart, kilip

how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• Developed in the 1960s, before reperfusion therapy (thrombolytics, PCI); however, has been shown across several studies since then to still be predictive of mortality.
  • Mortality rates have declined significantly since the original study.
  • Can be used in both STEMI and NSTEMI.
how_to_use.why_use_en: Predicts mortality in ACS and is validated for both STEMI and NSTEMI.

next_steps.advice_en: Can be used as part of the full clinical picture to help decide among treatment options, including reperfusion therapy and intra-aortic balloon pump placement.

about.formula_en:
Killip classification:

Class I

No signs of congestion

Class II

S3 and basal rales on auscultation

Class III

Acute pulmonary edema

Class IV

Cardiogenic shock

Original/Primary Reference.text: Killip T, Kimball JT. Treatment of myocardial infarction in a coronary care unit. A two year experience with 250 patients. Am J Cardiol. 1967;20(4):457-64.

Validation.text: Khot UN, Jia G, Moliterno DJ, et al. Prognostic importance of physical examination for heart failure in non-ST-elevation acute coronary syndromes: the enduring value of Killip classification. JAMA. 2003;290(16):2174-81.

DeGeare VS, Boura JA, Grines LL, O'neill WW, Grines CL. Predictive value of the Killip classification in patients undergoing primary percutaneous coronary intervention for acute myocardial infarction. Am J Cardiol. 2001;87(9):1035-8.

Nesković AN, Otasević P, Bojić M, Popović AD. Association of Killip class on admission and left ventricular dilatation after myocardial infarction: a closer look into an old clinical classification. Am Heart J. 1999;137(2):361-7.

creator_info.about_en: Thomas Killip III, MD, is a professor of medicine and cardiology at Mount Sinai Beth Israel Hospital in New York City. He has published dozens of studies in cardiology since the 1960s. Dr. Killip is best known for the heart failure classification system that bears his name.
